question:
Question: After a mental breakdown and subsequent retirement, one monarch of this name and number had the corpses of dead relatives exhumed so that he could observe them. Another king of this name and number kept a mistress who was said to have once worked selling oranges. After a different king of this name and number died in Madrid in 1700, his famous autopsy reported that “his heart was (*) the size of a peppercorn” and that  “his head was full of water”. An English of this name and number granted amnesty to his entire kingdom except some of the “regicides” who had approved his father's execution. For ten points, what name and number are shared by the inbred last Hapsburg monarch of Spain, whose death sparked the War of the Spanish Succession, and a merry monarch who was restored to power after the death of Oliver Cromwell?

ANSWER: Charles II

Question: This operation began in 1973 when two agents got jobs at the IRS as clerk typists to as covers for their real jobs, which were to monitor files and make copies to send back to their superiors. This operation resulted in the largest raid in FBI history, involving 156 agents, lasted for 21 hours, and filled a 16-ton truck with documents and evidence. This operation continued for around four years until the two agents were caught stealing files by the night librarian at the federal courthouse in Washington DC. These two agents were Michael Meisner (*) and Gerald Bennet Wolfe, who were operatives for the Church of Scientology. For ten points, name this operation, named after a fictional princess, conducted by the Church of Scientology, the largest infiltration of the United States Government in history.

ANSWER: Operation Snow White

Question: This glam rock album was released in June of 1972. The cover of this album features a dimly lit street corner, on which stands a man with a guitar case. One song in this album is about a bisexual man with a roommate named Henry. The man pushes Henry away in favor of dating a strong-willed feminist. This album details a dying (*) earth that is visited by a mystical bisexual androgynous rock star from space. A song for this album was featured in Guardians of the Galaxy when it cut out right before the word “bitch”. For ten points, name this David Bowie album containing songs such as “Lady Stardust”, “Starman”, “Five Years” and “Moonage Daydream”.

ANSWER: The Rise and Fall of Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders From Mars (Prompt on "Stardust" before mentioned)

Question: Upon reaching the age of 83, a person may celebrate a second one of these events, which give those who have completed one moral responsibility their actions and eligibility to participate in a minyan. The name of this ritual usually translates to, "son (or daughter) of (*) commandment". Tefillin and Tallit can be worn as a result of this event. In preparation for this Semetic ceremony, many learn a Haftarah, and candy is often thrown at the person whom the event is honoring. For ten points, name this Jewish celebration for children who reach the age of 13.

ANSWER: Bar Mitzvah [or B’nai Mitzvah; accept Bat Mitzvah; prompt on coming of age or becoming an adult or other synonymous answers]

Question: This man had a debilitating fear his head would fall off while he was conducting, and he was known to drink only bottled water. An oboe plays a high A to begin the trio of a scherzo, and the strings play pizzicato throughout in his Symphony No. 4. A quintessentially Russian ballet (*) he wrote contains a "trepak", and some of its other sections represent coffee, tea, and chocolate. Another work of his includes a motif from La Marseillaise, and can end with the fire of an real cannon. For ten points, name this Russian composer of 1812 Overture, as well as the ballets Swan Lake and The Nutcracker.

ANSWER: Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky

Question: In one episode of this show a character asks his friend at a halloween party if he is handsome. Later in that episode another character takes drugs in order to prove that he is not old and is still cool. In another episode of this show a man claims he is taking a class taught by a man named (*) Professor Professorson. One of the main characters of this show charts his female friends’ menstrual cycles claiming that before he realized what he was doing the study had “yielded positive results. Some popular quotes in this show include: “I see your value now,” “Pop Pop!” and “6 seasons and a movie.” For 10 points, name this American sitcom, in which Jeff Winger is forced to attend Greendale in order to become a lawyer again.

ANSWER: Community

Question: In one episode in this text, a wealthy king tries to verify which oracles are trustworthy; the only one found to be so was Oracle of Delphi. That Lydian king is Croesus, who later goes on to give questionable advice to Cyrus (*) the Great before he battles the Massagetaeians. In a different passage of this work, the battle of Mycale is described, and Xerxes’s army is held for three days at Thermopylae pass by Leionidas. Cicero called the writer of this text the “father of history”, and he came from modern day Bodrum, then called Halicarnassus. For ten points, name this often fanciful account by Herodotus.

ANSWER: The Histories

Question: In the Indian medicinal practice of Ayurveda, people with this trait are seen as likely to have a "Pitta" temperament, and many use henna and saffron to gain the appearance of having this characeristic. A posthumous portrait leads some to speculate Cleopatra possessed this trait, which was also exhibited, along with grey eyes, by the Scythians according (*) to Tang Dynasty accounts. An admiral with this characteristic conqured Tunis, and was employed by Suleiman the Magnificent. A Holy Roman Emperor with this attribute drowned in a Anatolian river en route to Jerusalem. For ten points, name this hair color shared by Thomas Jefferson, Lucille Ball, Emma Watson and Fredrick Barbarossa.

ANSWER: Red hair [accept red beard or other equivalent]

Question: East Germanic Gothic culture thrived in this area well into the 18th century, though the ethnically Gothic potentiate Theodoro fell 400 years prior. A pair of photographs taken in this region show a lanscape before and after a battle. Those pioneering photographs were taken by Roger Fenton. (*) A Mongol siege in this territory may have introduced the Black Plague to Europe, and Florence Nightingale gained fame for treating wounded soldiers here. The charge of the light brigade occurred on, for ten points, this peninsula on the northern coast of the Black Sea, in 2014 seized from Ukraine by the Russian Federation.

ANSWER: (the) Crimea

Question: The earliest fossils of organisms of this kingdom date back to more than 400 million years ago, and those organisms reproduce using spores. Those organisms were lycophytes, which are still around today. Members of this kingdom are also often known to possess such anatomy as phyllodes, petioles, (*) sepals and anthers. Those with reproductive organs called pistils and stamens are known as angiosperms, and Carnivorous members of this kingdom include “bladder” and “lobster-pot” varieties. Inability to digest the cellulose in their rigid cell walls is the reason humans can't eat paper. For ten points, identify this eukaryotic taxonomic kingdom whose members often perform photosynthesis and include shrubberies, flowers and trees.

ANSWER: Plants

Question: Hantaro Nagaoka’s rejected Saturnian version of this included electrically charged rings. Lord Kelvin originally devised an early one of these using the work of Alfred Mayer, and it was verified by Hans Geiger (*) and Ernest Marsden using, among other things, a tube containing radium and bismuth. A discovery by James Chadwick forced a revision of the “cloud” one of these and a “billiard ball” conception of this was put forth by John Dalton. For ten points, name these theories about the composition and structure of the basic particles of matter.

ANSWER: Atomic Models [accept equivlent]

Question: A son montuno band from this country, Sierra Maestra, is named for a mountain range found in its historical Oriente province. The national anthem of this country, the Bayamesa, draws its name from the city of Bayamo. The guajira band the Buena Vista Social (*) Club was formed in this country’s capital, which is served by José Martí International Airport. Perhaps this island country’s best known song, Guajira Guantanamera, references a woman from its Guantanamo province. For ten points, name this country, whose capital is referenced by Camila Cabello in the title of her 2018 hit, Havana.

ANSWER: Cuba

Question: This team, though founded in 1967, would not get its first winning season unitl 20 years later. Their owner, originally a car dealership owner, bought this team for a mere 70 dollars. Consistently wearing paper bags until the turn of the century, this team was marked as one of the worst in the NFL. Featuring such players such as Steve Gleason and such defenses such as the "dome patrol", this team aws the victim of the infamous "no call" in the 2018 NFC Championship game. For 10 points name this team that plays in New Orleans, quarterbacked by Drew Brees.

ANSWER: New Orleans Saints (accept new orleans before mention)

Question: The Dirac Quantization condition states that the product of the charge of these particles in terms of the fundamental unit of their charge and the fundamental unit of electric charge gives an integer multiple of pi in units of the reduced Planck’s constant. The first solution to the Yang-Mills Field equation was one of these entities named for Wu and Yang. (*) A Dirac string is a one-dimensional curve in space stretching between two of these particles with opposite charges or from one out to infinity. The Dirac string is the only way to incorporate these particles into Maxwell’s equations. Gauss’s law predicts that these particles do not exist. Name FTP these particles of singular magnetic charge that act “like a magnet with only a north or a south pole”.

ANSWER: Magnetic monopoles

Question: The first infinte sequence that was discovered in europe is equal to 2 over this number. Another infinite series for this number over 4 can be represented as the sum as k appraches infinity of (-1^k)/2k+1. That series is known is the leibniz formula for this quantity. A popular website allows the user to find any string of numbers in this quantity. This quantity can can also be represented as the ratio of a circles circumfrence over its diameter. For 10 points name this quantity that is squared in the formula for an area of a circle and is approximated to 3.14.

ANSWER: Pi [accept 3.14]

Question: This composer was instrumental in shaping the foundation of West Coast minimalism and the New York School through his frequent use of melody repetition and repetition in chord changes. This person was the composer-in-residence for the Mystical Order of the Rose and Cross of the Temple and Grail , an occult group of people founded by one of this persons' close friends, Joséphin Péladan. After this composers' death,  his friends and family found over 100 umbrellas chaotically (*) spread throughout his house. This composer, known for his eccentricity, had a pedantic schedule, carried a hammer around for protection, and had a strange diet consisting of shredded bones, moldy fruit, and only the white varieties of cheese. This composer is also known for being a pioneer of background music, or what he called "furniture music". For 10 points, name this French composer of Gymnopedies Suite and Vexations, a piece that requires it to be repeated 840 times in succession.

ANSWER: Erik Satie [Alfred Leslie, accept Steve Reich until "melody repetition"]

Question: The motion of particles in one type of these devices is modeled by the Mathieu equation. That type of this device is named after Wolfgang Paul and got him and Hans Dehmelt the 1989 Nobel Prize in Physics. When decomposed into its normal modes, another type of this device possesses a negative quadratic term in its Hamiltonian. (*) In that type of one of these devices, the normal modes are referred to as the axial, magnetron, and modified cyclotron modes. One type of Quantum computers is named after these devices. A type of this device is used at CERN’s ALPHA experiment to store antimatter. For ten points, name these devices used to trap ions.

ANSWER: Ion traps [do not accept particle accelerators]

Question: This composer was a polyglot, speaking 15 languages fluently throughout his life. After a young death, his wife, Constanze, outlived him by more than 50 years. (*) She is part of the reason why he is recognized as one of the greatest composers of all time by spreading his music and preserving his legacy long after he was gone. This composer also had an unrefined sense of humor, for someone of his status. He constantly made jokes referring to the butt and sex. One of his pieces, Leck Mich im Arsch, or in English, "lick me in the arse," is a good example of this. This composer also went on tour all over Europe with his sister, Nannerl, and father, Leopold, at the age of 7. For 10 points, name this composer of The Magic Flute and Eine Kleine Nachtmusik.

ANSWER: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart

Question: In this work a prince takes a vow of lifelong celibacy in order to allow his father to marry a fisherman’s daughter. In another incident in this work, a woman turns pale and bloodless after seeing her first son which causes her second son to be born pale and unhealthy. Towards the end of this epic, characters fall on a trek up a mountain one by one with a man explaining why they each fell. In the most famous scene of this work, a charioteer explains to a warrior that it is his duty to fight for a righteous cause. That section of this epic is the primary holy scripture for Hinduism. For 10 points, name this ancient Indian epic that contains the Bhagavad Gita, and is about the conflict between the 5 Pandava brothers and the 100 Kaurava brothers for the throne of Hastinapura.

ANSWER: Mahabharata

Question: The earliest recorded case of this phenomenon is often attributed to John Locke in 1690, but there is disagreement as to whether he described an actual case or was using a metaphor. This involuntary phenomenon is also known to cause sensory overload in some of its patients. The most common variant of this phenomenon applies to letters (*) and numbers and is known as the Grapheme-color variety. Genetically, women are 8 times more likely to have this condition compared to men, in the UK. People experiencing this phenomenon in the field of music are also disproportinately likely to have perfect pitch. The word describing this phenomenon has Greek origins, it's components translating to "together-sensation".  For 10 points, name this phenomenon because of which people may "hear colors" or "see sounds".

ANSWER: Synesthesia [accept specific types]

Question: For ten points each, answer these questions about a novel in which the narrator is not from North Carolina:

[10] The African American protagonist moves to Harlem and joins the Brotherhood in this novel by Ralph Ellison.

ANSWER: Invisible Man [do not accept or prompt on The Invisible Man]

[10] The protagonist in Invisible Man, has this name.

ANSWER: (*psyke*) he is Unnamed [generously accept equivalents]

[10] The unnamed protagonist originally gets a job making this product.

ANSWER: White paint

Question: For ten points, answer these questions about Things Fall Apart:

[10] This Nigerian author wrote Things Fall Apart.

ANSWER: Chinua Achebe

[10] The title of Things Fall Apart is taken from this poem by William Yeats about a prophesied future event in Christianity.

ANSWER: The Second Coming

[10] Things Fall Apart opens in Umuofia, a village of this ethnic group whose members include Achebe. They are native to southeastern Nigeria.

ANSWER: Igbo people [or Ibo]

Question: For ten points each, answer these questions about “pales” in European geographic history:

[10] A region controlled by the English following the Battle of Crécy was known as the “Pale of” this channel port city. This city was later designated the “staple port” of wool exports from England due to its location on the Strait of Dover. Some wealthy merchants who lived here appeared in a famous painting.

ANSWER: Calais

[10] Catherine the Great established the “pale of settlement” in Western Russia, in which permanent occupancy by these people was permitted. Many of them lived in that areas’ shtetls.

ANSWER: Jews [accept equivalent]

[10] An area under the direct jurisdiction of the English crown, known as The Pale, was centered around this modern capital of Ireland.

ANSWER: Dublin

Question: For ten points each, answer these questions about ancient haircuts:

[10] This man popularized cropped hair and clean shavenness across his vast but short-lived empire, which extended from his home in Macedon to the Indus river.

ANSWER: Alexander the Great [Accept Alexander the Horseman, Alexander III]

[10] This other classical great wore his hair in an Alexander-esque style in an attempt to accentuate his resemblance with the great conqueror. His feats include being the last Roman to defeat Pontus's king Mithridates, clearing the Mediterranean of pirates, and taking credit for putting down Sparticus’s slave rebellion. He was beheaded in Egypt in 106 BCE.

ANSWER: Gnaeus Pompey the Great [accept Pompey Magnus; prompt on Pompey]

[10] This Germanic tribe’s distinctive haircut was called their namesake “knot”, and one subdivision of them, the Marcomanni, waged war on Rome during the reign of Marcus Aurelius. A modern region in Germany named for them contains the Black Forrest and the city of Augsburg.

ANSWER: The Suebians [prompt on Swabians, I guess]

[10] Around 1159 AD, this man’s mother, Hoelun, was kidnapped by his father, Yesügei, before her marriage to a member of a rival tribe could take place.

 

ANSWER: Genghis Khan [or Chinggis Khan; or Temujin; prompt on “Khan”]

 

[10] After founding the city of Rome, Romulus and his followers kidnapped and married women of this Italic tribe.

 

ANSWER: Sabines [or Sabini]

 

[10] The title character of this 2006 Sacha Baron Cohen mockumentary attempts to kidnap Pamela Anderson and bring her back to his home country of Kazakhstan.


ANSWER: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan

Question: For ten points each, answer these questions about socialism with following descriptors:

[10] This term was popularized during the reign of Deng Xiaoping and was associated with his efforts to liberalize the economy.

ANSWER: Socialism with Chinese Characteristics

[10]  This man sought to implement “Socialism with a human face” in Czechoslovakia as leader of the Prague Spring movement.

ANSWER: Alexander Dubcek

 

[10] “Socialism within capitalism” often describes this political and economic philosophy associated with Northern Europe that supports state intervention to promote societal justice.

ANSWER: Social Democracy [do not accept Democratic Socialism; prompt on welfare state]

Question: For ten points each, answer these questions on famous individuals with the surname Smith:

[10] This naval leader became an icon of "stiff upper lip" British discipline when, in 1912, he went down with his ship, the RMS Titanic.

ANSWER: Edward Smith

[10] This enthusiastic gardener was the last leader of the unrecognized southern African republic of Rhodesia.

ANSWER: Ian Smith

[10] This English political economist upended mercantilism with his tome, “An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations”.

ANSWER: Adam Smith

Question: The Thuggee, or Thugs, were highwaymen known for strangling travelers in British India. For ten points each:

[10] Their name comes from the word for concealment in this ancient Indian language of the Vedas.

ANSWER: Sanskrit

[10] Many Thuggee were devotees of this wife of Shiva and aspect of Durga, known to wield a sword and sport a necklace of human heads.

ANSWER: Kali

[10] Reference is made to the Thuggee with the line, “I laid traps for troubadours who get killed before they reach Bombay”, in Sympathy for the Devil, a song by this English rock band whose distinctive logo is inspired by the mouth of Kali.

ANSWER: The Rolling Stones

Question: For ten points each, answer these questions about science with preceding adjectives:

 

[10] Economics was called this by Thomas Carlyle in response to the gloomy predictions of Thomas Malthus.

 

ANSWER: Dismal science

 

[10] Friedrich Nietzsche proclaimed that "God is dead" in this work.

 

ANSWER: The Gay Science (or Die Fröhliche Wissenschaft; accept “The Happy Science” or other equivlents I guess… not somthing like “The Homosexual Science” obviously)

 

[10] This discredited discipline was often used to support “race science”. Practitioners used calipers to measure bumps on the skull, in the attempt to predict personality traits.


ANSWER: Phrenology

Question: Early in this narrative, the central character visits the resort town of Pola in Dalmatia, but the “Austrian” nature of the company there causes him to decide to travel West. That man, whose physical appearance is similar to that of Gustav Mahler, was said to have written an acclaimed prose epic about Fredrick the (*) Great. Another, younger character in this novella has nun-like sisters, and at one point passionately shows his hate for a group of Russians tourists. Most of the story takes place in a beachside hotel, and beyond its walls preparations are being made for the emergence of a cholera pandemic. For ten points, name this Thomas Mann novella in which writer Gustav Von Aschenbach stalks the pre-pubescent Tadzio in the title Italian city.

ANSWER: Death in Venice

Question: It's a 19th century anarchist brunch, and you're invited! For ten points each, find what the other guests are having:

 

[10] Russian anarcho-communist Peter Kropotkin is eating this staple, which he described the Conquest of in one famous work. Bhature is a deep fried kind of this food from Northern India.

 

ANSWER: Bread

 

[10] Christian Anarchist and writer Leo Tolstoy is vegetarian, meaning he is steering clear of this kind of food.

 

ANSWER: Meat [accept equivalents]

 

[10] German egoist Max Stirner is thirsty, and is drinking this beverage. He once lost his wife’s inheritance on a venture to distribute this drink throughout Berlin using anarchist principles. In Hindu religion, the demoness Putana attempted to kill Krishna by offering him a cup of this.


ANSWER: Milk

Question: For ten points each, answer these questions about the life of economist Ludwig Von Mises:

 

[10] Von Mises was born a subject of this European country, the birthplace of Hiter and Motzart. Its capital is Vienna.

 

ANSWER: Austria [accept Österreich or Austria-Hungary]

 

[10] In a series of private debates, Von Mises dissuaded the Otto Bauer from doing this action. This action was attempted in Germany during the Spartacist uprising.

 

ANSWER: Communist revolution [generously accept equivalent]

 

[10] On the 10th of April, 1947, Mises co-founded the Mont Pelerin Society, a classical Liberal think tank. At one meeting he is reported to have said, “You’re all a bunch of socialists!” to a group that included this influential Chicago school economist, known for his PBS series Free to Choose.


ANSWER: Milton Friedman

Question: For ten points each, answer these questions about notable people who played quizbowl:

[10] This possibly robotic founder and CEO of Facebook played Academic Challenge in high school, though only went to one tournament.

ANSWER: Mark Zuckerberg

[10] This far right blogger associated with the Dark Enlightenment coined the terms “the red pill” and “the cathedral” on his now defunct blog Unqualified Reservations. He played on Brown University’s team in the early 1990s.

ANSWER: Curtis Yarvin [Accept Mencius Moldbug]

[10] 2020 presidential hopeful Pete Buttigieg played quizbowl for two years in high school. He was once mayor of this city, adjcent to the University of Notre Dame.

ANSWER: South Bend

Question: With Francis Low, this man names a theorem that relates the ground state of an interacting system in QFT. With lévy, this scientist created the sigma model to describe pion interactions. With Feynman, this man posited a vector-minus axial Lagrangian for weak interactions. A formula named after him and Nijishima states that the charge equals isospin plus one-half times the baryon number plus strangeness. He predicted the omega minus particle as a result of his work with Yuval Ne'eman to organize particles based on their symmetric association, known as the eightfold way. For ten points name this physicist, winner of the 1969 Nobel Prize in Physics, and the man who postulated the existence of Quarks.

Answer: Murray Gell-Mann

Question: Its not Einstein, but during this man’s annus mirabilis, he developed and verified his theories on the composite nature of light, that light was made of discrete particles. He also refined his theory of gravitation to the point that he was able to satisfy himself through the calculation relating the interaction between the (*) earth and the moon. Along with the previous Lucasian professor at Cambridge, this man invented the fluxion, creating calculus. The namesake of the SI unit of Force, for ten points, name this scientist with three namesake laws of motion who discovered the law of Universal Gravitation.

Answer: Isaac Newton

Question: Emily Wilson is currently translating this work, which, in its original language, begins with the line, “Menin aeide thea Peleiadeo Achilleos oulomenin”. The “doloneia” section of this poem is commonly seen as extraneous, and William Gladstone noticed it never mentions the (*) color blue. The Catalogue of Ships in this epic poem describes the ethnic composition of an army, in which the Acheans have a leading role. This work ends with Priam begging for the body of his son Hector, who was killed by Achilles. For ten points, name this chronologically earliest epic poem by Homer.

ANSWER: The Iliad

Question: Though his army received supplies from the abandoned Panuco River settlement, soldiers under this man were the last in Western history to use trebuchets due to a shortage of gunpowder. He was thought by his enemies to have arrived on a one reed year, and he had a decades long feud with Governor Diego (*) Velazquez. Much of his army drowned during the Noche Triste massacre, but he was able to escape and regroup in Tlaxcala territory. He was helped in a number of different ways by the Mayan interpreter La Malinche. He established New Spain and conquored Tenochtitlan. For ten points, name this Spanish Conquistador who overthrew Montezuma and ended the Aztec empire.

ANSWER: Hernán Cortés [prompt on Quetzalcoatl]

Question: Roccella montagnei and Dendrographa leucophoea are the main sources for the production of this thing. This thing owes it's main properties to a 7-hydroxyphenoxazone chromophore. It was first used in the 1300s by Spanish physician Arnaldus de Villa Nova (*) and it's principle constituents have an average molecular mass of 3300. Some fractions of this thing were given names inclduing erythrolitmin, azolitmin, spaniolitmin, leucoorcein, and leucazolitmin. Chlorine gas can turn the blue kind of this thing white, an irreversible change due to the presence of hypochlorite ions. For 10 points, name this indicator extracted from lichens, the blue and red variety of which are often used as acid-base detectors.

Answer: Litmus (Prompt on indicator until read)

Question: A language isolate is one which cannot be found to descend from an ancestor common to any other language. For ten points each, answer these questions about language isolates found in the Indian Subcontinent:

 

[10] Long thought to be extinct, a handful of speakers of this country’s Kusunda language isolate were unexpectedly discovered in the early 2000s. They were found in Dang province, not far from its capital, Kathmandu.

 

ANSWER: Nepal

 

[10] Though its speakers claim desent for soldiers under Alexader the Great, this language shows no relationship to Greek, Macedonian or any others. It is spoken by around 100 thousand, concentrated in Pakistan’s Hunza valley, and is hypothesized to be the origin of the word for “apple” in Indo-European languages.

 

ANSWER: Burushaski [Accept Biltum, Khajuna, Kunjut, Brushaski, Burucaki, Burucaski, Burushaki, Burushki, Brugaski, Brushas or Werchikwar]

 

[10] The Nihali language isolate is found in the Indian state of Madhya Pradesh. Today it is spoken by less than 2000 and serves as this kind of language, used to exclude or mislead outsiders. These kinds of languages are often associated with criminality.

 

ANSWER: Argot [Accept anti-language, cryptolect, cant, or thieves’ cant]

Question: Conglomerates are large corporations that often have many specialised subsidaries that serve different industries. For 10 points each, answer these questions about conglomerates.

[10] A prominent 400-year-old German industrial corporation from Essen, this conglomerate originally specialised in steelworking, but later became a major weapons supplier to multiple sides throughout various conflicts, and was sometimes blamed for the wars themselves or the degree of carnage that ensued. This company produced the steel used to build railroads in the United States and to cap the Chrysler Building. During the time of the Third Reich, this company supported the Nazi regime and used slave labour. In 1999 this company merged with Thyssen AG to become one of the world's largest industrial engineering companies.

ANSWER: Krupp or the Friedrich Krupp Company

[10] This term is used to describe large conglomerates from Japan, historically those whose influence and size allowed control over significant parts of the Japanese economy from the Meiji period until the end of World War II. The so called "big four" of these conglomerates include Sumitomo, Mitsui, Mitsubishi, and Yasuda. The Japanese government attempted to dissolve many of these companies after World War 2, however the United States government rescinded these orders in an effort to reindustrialize Japan as a bulwark against communism in Asia.

ANSWER: Zaibatsu (prompt on "financial clique")

[10] This modern day producer of adhesives and safety equipment was founded as the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company in Two Harbors, Minnesota. In 2016, a complaint was filed against this company for knowingly selling defective earplugs issued to military personnel deployed to Iraq and Afghanistan resulting in them paying a $9.1 million settlement to the U.S. government. This conglomerate is based in Saint Paul and is said to be the largest of its kind in the world.

ANSWER: 3M Company or 3M

Question: Burn your draft card and blast Fortunate Son as you answer these questions about the Vietnam War. For 10 points each:

[10] Despite proclaiming non-allignment during the Cold War, this country sent medical supplies and doctors to aid and train the Vietcong in response to the American involvement in the war. This country's government granted American war resisters asylum status and the general public of this country openly welcomed them.

ANSWER: Sweden

[10] This senior general in the Army of the Republic of Vietnam was oftened referred to by a nickname that reflected the fact that at approximately 6 ft tall and weighing 198 lb, he was much larger than the average Vietnamese. This South Vietnamese politician became chief of a military junta after leading a coup in which Ngo Dinh Diem was assassinated and was later the fourth and last President of South Vietnam.

ANSWER: Dng Vn Minh or Big Minh

[10] This location was the home and workplace of the President of South Vietnam during the Vietnam War. On 27 February 1962, two pilots of Republic of Vietnam Air Force bombed this location's original building in an attempted assassination of Diem. On 8 April 1975, Nguyn Thanh Trung, a pilot of the South Vietnamese air force and an undetected communist spy bombed this location again and 22 days later, a tank of the North Vietnamese army bulldozed through this location's main gate, effectively ending the Vietnam War.

ANSWER: Independence Palace (Prompt on Norodom Palace and Reunification Convention Hall)

Question: The sculptor of this work is believed to have based its figure off the discus thrower Nina Dumbadze while its face was based off his wife Vera.  The construction of this monument was started by an engineer and a sculptor in May 1959 and completed on 15 October 1967 at which it was the tallest sculpture in the world at the time. This work is the tallest statue in Europe (*) and the tallest statue of a woman in the world. The technology behind this hollow statue is based on a combination of prestressed concrete with wire ropes, a solution which can also be found in the Ostankino Tower, another work of this statue's creators. A copy of this statue can be found in Manzhouli, China. This statue features an 85-metre (279 ft) figure of a woman stepping forward with a raised sword. For ten points, name this statue displayed in Volgograd that is an allegorical image of the Motherland, which calls on its sons and daughters to repulse the enemy and return to the attack.

ANSWER: The Motherland Calls

Question: This man kept two pet lion cubs, which he named Tax Reduction and Budget Bureau. A graduate of Amherst college, he was especially influenced by his philosophy professor Charles Garman. During his two year long vice presidency, a deflationary recession was responded to by then secretary of commerce Herbert Hoover, and as president, he worked (*) with Andrew Mellon to implement “scientific taxation”, an early version of supply side economics. His administration was criticized for its slow response to the Great Mississippi Flood. He came to national attention after putting down the Boston Police strike of 1918, and was said to have told a woman “you lose” when she bet he would say more than two words. For ten points, name this taciturn successor of president Warren Harding.


ANSWER: Calvin Coolidge [Prompt on “Silent Cal”]

Question: For ten points, answer these questions about the Hoover Institution:

[10] The Hoover Institution was named for this 31st President of the United States. The Great Depression, which began during his first and only term, led to his loss against Franklin Roosevelt in the election of 1932. 

ANSWER: Herbert Hoover

[10] The Hoover Institution is part of this university, of which Herbert Hoover was often considered the first graduate. The founder of this school, Leland, was the Presient of the Central Pacific Railroad, and he conducted the driving of the golden spike which completed the Transcontinental Railroad.

ANSWER: Stanford University

[10] This former speechwriter hosts the interview show Uncommon Knowledge for the Hoover Institution. He was 30 years old when he wrote the “Tear Down this Wall” speech.

ANSWER: Peter Robinson

Question: This 18th century composer was instrumental in the development of chamber music such as the piano trio. His contributions to musical form have earned him the epithets "Father of the Symphony" and "Father of the String Quartet". He, along with other contemporary composers, participated in the "Sturm und Drang" stylistic period from the late 1760s to the early 1760s.  One of his pieces, a personal anthem for Emperor Francis II titled "Gott erhalte Franz den Kaiser", has lent (*) its melody to the modern day anthem of Germany. "Gott erhalte Franz den Kaiser" allegedly took its melody from a Croation folk song titled "Stal se jesem" and similar inspirations have led some historians to question whether he was actually of Croation descent. For ten points name this Austrian born composer who was a friend and mentor of Mozart, a tutor of Beethoven, and the older brother of composer Michael Haydn.

ANSWER: Franz Joseph Haydn

Question: A traditional British marching song claims that while "Some talk of Alexander, and some of Hercules. Of Hector and Lysander, and such great names as these", the "world's bravest heroes" are in fact these specialized infantry units. These units were often considered the first "elite troops" adopted by European militaries, with British diarist John Evelyn comparing them to the elite Ottoman Janissary troops. By 1700, units bearing this title had adopted a cap in the shape of a bishop's mitre (*), a descendant of which can be seen in the form of the Bearskin cap that is worn by the modern British Royal Guards. These units originally served purposes similar to shock troops, but also had duties that overlap with those commonly attributed to combat engineers or sappers. For ten points, name these specialized troops whose name is derived from the explosive metal spheres they hurled during battle.

ANSWER: Grenadiers

Question: The earliest known reference to this mathematical algorithm is in Nicomachus of Gerasa's "Introduction to Arithmetic", and algorithms serving the same purpose have been named after both Sundaram and Atkin. The time complexity of this algorithm can be found using the formula O(n log log n), provided that the array update is an O(1) operation.(*) This algorithm is a popular way to benchmark computer performance and Euler's proof of the zeta product formula contains a version of this algorithm in which each composite number is eliminated exactly once. This algorithm operates  iteratively marking as composite the multiples of each prime, starting with the first prime number, 2. The multiples of a given prime are generated as a sequence of numbers starting from that prime, with constant difference between them that is equal to that prime. For ten points, name this ancient algorithm used to find all prime numbers up to any given limit.

ANSWER: Sieve of Eratosthenes

Question: In this novel an allusion is made to Lothrop Stoddard, when a character talks about a novel promoting white supremacy. This novel opens with the narrator commenting about advice he was given by his father in his younger years about judging people. One person in this novel claims the title character is the nephew of Kaiser Wilhelm. This title character works with Meyer Wolfsheim who supposedly fixed a World Series. Another character in this novel is named for the type of spectacles he wears. That character and the narrator, Nick Carraway, are the only people who attend the title character’s funeral. For 10 points, name this novel set in the jazz age that features characters such as Owl-Eyes, Tom and Daisy Buchanan, and Jordan Baker who all attend lavish parties thrown by the title character, written by F. Scott Fitzgerald. 


Answer: The Great Gatsby
